Comment: Seattle based filmmakers from Rooted in Rights made a documentary on workers with disabilities who are paid subminimum wages. In the past year, it has been shown at around Seattle at the SIFF Uptown, Starbucks HQ, Seattle University, and the University of Washington as well as at hundreds of other locations across the country, including Capitol Hill in DC. It is now available to stream or download for those who want to get to know what it is like for workers with disabilities who are paid below minimum wage and compare that to others who are treated fairly. https://vimeo.com/ondemand/bottomdollars
There is a growing movement across this country supporting the elimination of subminimum wages for people with disabilities, but very few jurisdictions have actually done it. It is great that Seattle is looking to lead the way here in Washington.

Comment: The modern conservative movement did begin in the Eisenhower years and received its intellectual rationale from William Buckley's 'National Review.' The movement took a hit from the Goldwater campaign and defeat, but got back on track during the Reagan years. Gingrich and the shutdown of the government that he engineered marked a devolution from the conservative movement, a detour from the principles of mainstream conservatism.  It's been downhill from there: the rise of the religious right; the Tea Party (or Parties); the blatant racism of the birtherism drivel; the alt-right; culminating in the nomination by the Republican party of an unabashedly fascist, racist know-nothing blowhard.  This is not something that happened overnight; and it was not a stealth operation. Comment: The union cited in this article is doing a great disservice to the union movement in general and public service unions in particular. At a time of declining union representation in the workplace there is a perception, among a sizeable part of society,  that trade unions somehow foster inefficiency and featherbedding. I believe this notion to be unfounded. The actions of the union leadership representing these fire fighters promotes all the worn platitudes about unions.
Rather than encouraging its members to work as volunteers, within the scope of their training, for the benefit of the greater community the leadership of this union would rather squander the resources of the organization they  represent and the public purse.  No benefit can accrue to the union, its membership or the community by  forcing committed individuals to stop volunteering.

Comment: Many people seem to think that there is some kind of anti-NDP lesson to be found in the Alberta government. 
In Alberta the conservatives had a 40+ year run. There were many economic ups and downs but mostly up due to petro wealth. But they spent every nickel while times were booming and when the price of oil fell they had no savings to fall back on.
Like most long running governments they became corrupt and not even the Albertans who supported them for half a century could stomach voting for them.
Now the Alberta NDP have to try to find a way out of 40+ years of Conservative corruption and fiscal recklessness.
Is the Alberta NDP party going to be perfect? Pretty unlikely. But the deep financial hole left over from the conservatives cannot be blamed on the NDP. The current low price of oil cannot be blamed on the NDP.
Maybe the comparison with BC is that the BCLibs have driven the province into debt through corrupt management and it's time to ask the NDP to clean this up.

Strikes and mass action are solutions against EMPLOYER abuses - not government abuses - it only overlaps in those cases where the employer is the government - and even then having MPs in parliament doesn't change their need since it's the civil service, not parliament, that does the employing.

Strikes are disruptive of course, they are meant to be, and there is a simple bit of maths you can do. Instead of wailing about what it costs the country when some union goes on strike - do the math. That cost - the total combined cost to the ENTIRE economy that their strike imposed, is the actual value of their labour TO the economy.
Now subtract their actual wages from that cost - and if the difference is too large, you understand two things (1) why strikes are needed and (2) just how severe the theft of capitalism truly is.

It is impossible, through the mere withdrawel of labour, to cost the economy one cent more than the VALUE of your labour.

Comment: The US negotiators appear to be trying to force Mexico and Canada to walk away from the negotiations. This has obvious political consequences.

RC wants to opt out of NAFTA. So far there is little political will in Congress and Senate for this. However, if Mexico and Canada walked away from the talks first that would change. He would use our "refusal" to negotiate as an act of bad faith to persuade those who are ambivalent to his side.

The appropriate approach for Mexico and Canada is to stay at the bargaining table until the bitter end of the final round, rejecting all US positions that are unfair, making counter proposals that are fair to all.

After the final round, and assuming there is no deal, RC will be opting out of NAFTA before negotiations are complete which will not sit well with those who want to negotiate.

There is no doubt in my mind that RC will scuttle the trade deal at first opportunity. 

The only question is whether or not we give him an excuse.

Comment: In Canada, doctors are not allowed to kill patients; only to assist those patients in committing suicide.  There is a difference.  
Adults have the right to make choices about themselves.  We may disagree with those choices and believe that they are wrong, but the choice belongs to the person in question.  Giving a person a choice is not the same as "delivering a person to her/his death".  It seems to me that by assuming responsibility for that patient's ultimate decision, you are, in a way, trying to exceed God, since even God gives us free will.   
Children must be guided by adults.  If adults guide them to cocaine dealers, that is not good, because a child cannot always be expected to make a soundly reasoned choice.   It would be the same if one were to lead an addict to a dealer, because the addict is not making sound decisions.  
A terminally ill person may or may no be capable of making sound decisions, depending on the given circumstances.  That's why they consult doctors.

Comment: Historically... Agriculture employed 60% of the workforce in the 1850s, but mechanization has reduced the need to about 3%. The workforce shifted to industry and manufacturing, which peaked at over 35% of the workforce in the 1950s, but automation and global trade is reducing the need. The workforce shifted to services, which now employ over 75% of the workforce. But just as mechanization and automation reduced the need for farmers and factory workers, artificial intelligence (e.g. autonomous cars, online personal assistants, etc) is emerging that will reduce the need for service workers. And there's no emerging sector to pick up the slack in employment. There simply isn't enough work to employ everyone (at least, not where humans are better and cheaper than machines and computers).

However I disagree on Amazon... Both Amazon and Google are betting big on Deep Learning Neural Networks, which have the potential for be more disruptive than Blockchain distributed networks.

Comment: The sad ending to the PFD debate is that this is an issue of state spending. Government is built to spend. We have a deficit now, which they can partially close with the PFD monies. However, next year, that deficit grows again. And then it grows again. Because the government spends 100% every year, they are always in a deficit position unless growth in taxes out paces growth in spending, which is unlikely. The issue here has and always will be state spending. A system where it is ok to not spend 100% of your budget needs to be put into place. A system where departments can control funds and set aside funds for the future investments at the department level. That system needs to have incentives for managing our money properly. Without that, it is just spend spend spend and deficit deficit deficit. The PFD funds only help solve the current year and then we are talking about the rest of the PFD next year.

Comment: "That’s why the Trudeau government is right: It’s possible to meet Canada’s climate-change commitments while growing the economy, and even growing the oil industry."

I wonder if the editorial board read the op/ed by Kathryn Harrison in yesterday in this very paper before writing theirs. Her point is that building the pipeline is essentially betting that the Paris Climate Agreement will fail as it assumes a continually increasing demand for Canada's oil beyond 2020. So the government can't have it both ways: either we take our Paris commitments seriously or we do not. 

Canada is currently on track to miss our Paris targets in 2020 by a wide margin. How is increasing oil production going to help with this? I would love for the G&M, or anyone for that matter, to explain to me exactly how we can meet our climate change commitments while growing the oil industry because I haven't seen any such plan. Comment: I agree with Id99 that you can't say whether her portfolio is appropriate or not, without knowing her other financial information. Do the dividends cover her expenses? Maybe she has more dividends than she even needs? Does she have other non-income-producing assets, such as a paid-up home? Does she have long-term-care insurance?

I know someone a bit younger than your example who is almost 100% equity, owns a multi-million-$ home (easy in Toronto), and doesn't need bonds and such to reduce her risk. 

Yes, it would help to have 3-5 years' expenses-minus-dividends in short-term bonds, plus some funds for emergency expenses. But short of a 2009 meltdown, someone with a dividend growth portfolio who lost 20% stock value (and maybe 10% dividends with dividend cuts) would probably still be only set back to values / dividends of 5 years ago.

Comment: "Why is demonstrating against demonstrators a “stunt” on one side and not the other?"
.
It has nothing to do with sides. For instance, both "sides" of the statue removal protests and counter-protests were called demonstrations. What differentiates a "stunt" is the dishonesty. A legitimate demonstration honestly announces what it is and why, usually ahead of time. A "stunt" misrepresents some significant part of the event. In this case, Pence tried to claim that he had gone there to watch the game, and that his walkout was a spontaneous reaction to the kneeling. We have since learned that neither was the case. Thus, Pence's staged walkout was a "stunt" rather than a "demonstration".

Comment: OK.  Then how is that lost revenue made up for?

One of the issues is capital gains.  Let's say your uncle owned a rental house that he bought for $100,000.  At the time of his death it was worth $500,000.  The gain ($400K) he would have realized if he sold it would have been considered a capital gain and taxed at 15%, which comes to $60K.

You inherit the place and sell it the next day for $505K. You only pay tax on the $5K.  The other $400K in gains magically disappeared.  Change the $500K to $500M and it's still the same concept.  

Your uncle wasn't going to miss the $60K - he's dead.  You don't have much cause to complain - you just inherited a net $440K after the tax.  Who gets hurt are the other taxpayers in this country who have to pay the difference.

Apparently it's not true.  Death is certain, but taxes aren't.

Comment: The accident happened on Honoapiilani (30) Hwy just north of Kaanapali Parkway and just south of the Kualapa Lp. overpass. The northbound road rises about 100 feet between those two points. The road here is four lanes wide with a three foot wide painted divider - the heavy solid diagonal yellow stripes between two parallel courses of double yellow lines favored by Hawaii's highway department. The speed limit is 40 mph. Traffic never moves at the speed limit - 60 mph is typical when the road is clear. The road is poorly lit at night.  Another accident occurred 100 feet north of this spot on July 24. I've been driving this stretch of road several times a day for 20 years and have never seen traffic enforcement here. The road here, as could pretty much most of Honoapiilani Hwy, would be inexpensively improved by the installation of an actual physical divider between lanes. Unfortunately, the safety of Maui's roads is not a concern for either elected officials or the HI Highway Department.

Comment: Eliane, I may be wrong, but it seems to me that Cardinal Bernardin was not saying that each of us had to be equally activist in all pro-life activities, but to recognize that they are inseparable from one another. Can we say we are pro-life if we don't care about children living in poverty while we campaign to overturn Roe? Can we be advocating for war, supporting the death penalty, or supporting programs that gut education, food stamps or care for the mentally ill and be considered pro-life? As I understand it, the crux of his position was that they cannot be viewed as independent issues, but as all aspects of the same cloth. It is a strength that people are called to different aspects of Catholic Social Teaching, for each of them is critically important. That is the beauty of the seamless garment - the issues are integrally connected just as we are, just different colors in the tapestry.

Comment: This issue, in a nutshell, explains the conceit of the Liberal's claim that they make decisions based on "evidence based reasoning."

In the modern, real world, issues are complicated, and decision making is based upon competing interests, values, and (yes) various predictions based on existing evidence.

Here, you have an issue on what blood alcohol limit is the cutoff limit (legally, you can be impaired without being over 08).  Any limit, by its nature, is in a sense arbitrary.

While it is a valuable debate, and the 08 limit isn't sacrosanct, I believe it should be kept.  For the reasons mentioned in the article, and because most drunk driving accidents feature drivers way above the 08 limit.

More concerning, for a "rights" party, the Liberals seem to be intent on stepping on them.  No "reasonable suspicion" for a breath sample.  Far worse, the Liberals legislation to cripple the accused defense in a sexual assault trial.

And yet, Wilson thinks mandatory minimums violate rights.

Comment: China has issues with the rule of law, and human rights. But does anyone really care? The extradition treaty with China is unlikely to impact everyday Canadians. The only people that should be worried are Chinese citizens living in Canada.  So why do normal Canadians, those born here care?

I agree that some Chinese living in Canada might be innocent, but you have to assume that some accused of corruption or fraud are ACTUAL criminals. They defraud people in China, escape to Canada, and then defraud actual Canadians. The victims of extradition aren't even Canadian...

Obviously the chance of a Chinese criminal committing the same crime in Canada is small. But an extradition treaty does NOTHING that would hurt real Canadians. Yet, it prevents Canada from becoming a haven for Chinese criminals that might commit the same crimes against Canadians... if Canada gets more favorable trade terms with China out of this, its a Win-win IMO. Sucks for Chinese immigrants. But great for Canada.

At first glance, I like the new tax plan but the devil is in the details.  Work-Income credits and child care credits don't mean much for us senior citizens.

Comment: The UO is on *very* shaky Constitutional ground with this report—which raises serious First Amendment issues. Nor does the report address Professor Shurtz’s rights under Article I, section 8, of the Oregon Constitution.  Anyone pumping their fist better chill out and sit down—because this could very easily blow up in the university's face—and become an example to every other university who casually tramples on free speech.

The First Amendment contains nothing about students being "uncomfortable." The UO can no more dictate when and where the First Amendment applies than it can dictate Trump's foreign policy.

Almost nobody condones Professor Shurtz's thoughtless act. But for the university to even vaguely flirt with ideas like discomfort "outweighing" an individual's constitutional protection is setting a VERY bad precedent.

These fresh pure ground waters, or abzu, are impossibly precious, and thanks to profoundly destructive exploitative mismanagement of private capital, we've allowed someone's short-term profit motive to take these pure deep source away from posterity, forever.

How do you ensure containment of petrochemical deposits from ground water when you've connected them all with drilled holes and then plugged them with well casings that may hold out as long as another century before failing to prevent cross-contamination where they have not in fact already failed? Any assurance given seems non-credible.

Comment: I didn't say I got anything out of it.  I learned 8 years worth of sobriety.  Here's how the program works...a newcomer comes in and he is told to find a sponser. You see, AA was founded in 1935 and has literally not changed the first 164 pages of the big book in all this time, regardless of how much knowledge we have gained around alcoholism and drug addiction. Southpark does a wonderful explanation of AA.

Comment: OK, let's parse what you write:
1) ... the illusion that taxing carbon use will lower carbon footprint.  Are you suggesting it will not?  Are you suggesting that increasing price will not decrease usage?  In what economic world is that true?
2) We are a tiny producer, so our changes can not make a difference.  Well, if you divide up the producer base finely enough then everyone is a small producer and no-one can make a difference.  This is a pretty basic fallacy.  If we are 4% of world production, we can make a small difference, but not an insignificant difference.  AND new technologies that we develop can/will make it easier for larger countries with poorer technology bases to make a difference.  Otherwise it is a race to the bottom and we all get to have air quality like Beijing.  Is that your favored alternative?  Not mine.

Comment: Yes, that is exactly what the Oregon Supreme Court has ruled.  For instance on the COLA changes initiated two years ago.  Retirement benefits accrued prior to the legislation will receive the traditional 2% COLA.  Retirement benefits earned after the legislation will receive the new lower COLAs.  So, the employee in your example will receive a "blended" COLA with some of his/her retirement check getting the 2% and some the lesser %.   Same thing happened in 2003 when part of the retirement benefit was shifted to the IAP for existing workers.  As long as the change is not retroactive to already-earned benefits the courts allow it.

Comment: "it violates transgenders' human rights to privacy?"
The US has never recognized a broad category of "human rights."  The law still provides different levels of protection to suspect classes.  For example, discrimination based on race or religion are strongly protected while discrimination based upon sexual orientation or age are hardly protected at all (with some change in the winds).  Because there is no state or federal law that protects "transgenders' human rights" as a suspect class they are still freely discriminated unless a law or ordinance specifically protects, like Title 5 of the muni code. Comment: McGuigan doesn’t say it, but the case for more government control over the US Fed is quite strong. If one looks at other central banks in the Anglosphere. The Bank of England receives its inflation-targeting remit from the Chancellor of the Exchequer, and the Governor must write a letter to the Chancellor if the inflation rate is outside of the target range. For the Bank of Canada, the Reserve Bank of Australia and the Reserve Bank of New Zealand, the parameters of the inflation-targeting regime are mutually agreed upon by the central bank governor and the minister responsible for fiscal policy in the government. There is a strong case to be made that there should be regular signed agreements between the Treasury Secretary and the Chair of the US Fed on the parameters of the inflation targeting regime.

Comment: What I've always found troubling is the arbitrary, bureaucratic requirement that a person needs three times the income to pay the rent.  That requirement immediately disqualifies most of the people making the median income.

The reality of the situation is that a lower income person has to spend more than a third of their income on rent -- on up to pretty close to their entire income on rent and other fixed costs, like food, transportation, clothing.  They don't need to reserve another third of their income for travel, entertainment, gifts, insurance, retirement savings, fine dining, cigarettes and alcohol, etc.   They have to spend every penny on actual basic needs.  Otherwise, you arbitrarily disqualify huge swaths of the population from even being considered from the housing stock.

In a real world example, a $100 rent increase would then require a person to have a $300 pay increase to cover it -- which of course immediately makes the problem grow worse -- often just by writing it.

Comment: I spoke with a homeless lady (about 35 years old, reasonable, hapa, homeless for about 5 years)  on Sunday at the car wash on Beretania and Keeaumoku. I asked how the sweeps are affecting her, and she said that she just does not have much stuff anymore. She said the IHS shelters are full of bed bugs, most people she knows use them only as a last resort because they are so gross. I said that I disagree with the sweeps, and wondered what she wishes the City would invest in to actually help people like her. She praised the efforts to get people into homes. But added that "people like me" - who have extremely bad credit - will never get approved for rentals, and never get hired for job - after years of trying, she felt there is little point in trying. So two things occur to me: 1. Why does IHS have a near-monopoly on homeless services in Honolulu? Their "make people bottom out" philosophy is so harsh and judgey. 2. What can we do to help people in poverty (re)build their financial lives?

Comment: Image manipulation could defeat this system but it would just result in the image being discarded from the system for classification.  You wouldn't really be defeating anything.

I don't work at Facebook but probably what they are doing is analyzing a ton of nude images of regular people to create a features database that can quickly analyze shapes and lines in an image and give back a probabilistic result that any future input image contains a nude person.  This will probably be used for early detection and prevention.

If done properly, there would be no feasible way for a person to retrieve any source images without having every other source image (or most of them).  These systems combine large amounts of information to derive very general features that aren't specific to individuals and the original data is thrown away.

My own opinion is that while this may have good intentions and even be safe to some extent, you never have to worry about nude images you never take.

Comment: The problem is mostly with how the city makes a lane end (I'm not talking about closed lanes in construction zones).  Other countries have a proper "zipper" where instead of the right or left lane ending, forcing people to merge, both lanes "end" and come together in an upside down V and each lane has arrows letting drivers know that BOTH lanes need to merge together.  This eliminates the illusion that people in the ending lane are trying to cut into the continuing lane, because both "end" and merge into one.  The arrows on the road point towards the middle and the white dashed lane dividing line disappears, and then the road narrows.  This would solve lots of issues.  

Also, cities need to stop making a 2-lane road turn into a 1-lane road immediately after an intersection.  It just causes people to try to drag race when the light turns green to get ahead.  Blame city planning for all of it.

Comment: "Within a second someone proposes limiting the number of shells in a clip the right wing translates that to mean confiscation."

Because there's evidence that banning sales/transfers of magazines that hold more than some arbitrary number of cartridges does, in fact, eventually lead to confiscation (or its equivalent).

For example: California. As of July 1, 2017, subject to extremely limited exceptions, private possession of a "Large-Capacity Magazine" (more than 10 rounds) is illegal in CA. Prior to that, CA law prohibited the sale/transfer of LCMs, but grandfathered those magazines already owned. Owners of LCMs were given 3 "options":
1. surrender the LCM to law enforcement
2. sell the now-worthless LCM to a licensed firearms dealer
3. remove the LCM from the state
If you're caught with an LCM, you go to jail. That's about as close to "confiscation" as we can get, without door-to-door searches.
(FWIW, enforcement of this new law is on hold due to a federal court decision.)

Comment: I think all members of congress/senate should be limited to 2 consecutive terms (12 years total).  However, I think that term should be extended if that person is elected to a main leadership role within their party (such as Minority/Majority Leader), at which point the person is granted 2 additional terms.  This would limit the maximum time a person can serve in the House/Senate to 24 years - which, in my opinion, is more than enough time for a person to be in that type of position.  If they are interested in staying in DC, they can run for a different elected position.  

This process would keep the blood fresh in DC, and get out the stale old partisan politicians who have refused to cross the aisle their entire life.  It would also force the public to be slightly more involved in politics instead of just voting for the same guy for every election just due to name recognition.

Comment: I am a licensed community-association manager.  This requirement has not affected my competency, professionalism or honesty in any way.  And I know of no manager's whose competency has been increased by this law.  In my 23rd year of successful management, I was required to take beginning-level courses, which bored me to no end, and I had to pay unnecessary fees.  The classes alone cost me $495.00.  I passed the state test.  Took me 19 minutes to complete. It had been predicted that this law would result in a dearth of managers, and that has happened.  I see no reason to keep the law.

The real problem with common-interest communities is the boards, or, more specifically, the directors on those boards.  They are the ones who make the decisions, not the managers.  The managers usually just do as instructed.  What is needed is some way to hold directors responsible for their actions. 
Also, what is needed is a mandatory and binding dispute-resolution process to settle disputes.

Comment: Planners in jurisdictions around the world have already figured out that there is no possible way to build enough capacity to match the demand for road space. Every increase in capacity is instantly filled by drivers choosing to get into (or back into) cars. 

The only way to keep up with demand is to get people out of single-occupancy vehicles and into car pools, transit, onto their feet and riding bikes. 

Vancouver is even more hamstrung by this reality thanks to the defeat of the downtown parkway project. Increasing downtown access would require huge expropriations and the extra capacity would be filled instantly by commuters getting back into their cars. 

This is what data, logic and research says.

Comment: Although you indicate that the Refuge and a large private landowner are willing to exchange land to make a proposed Juneau Creek alternative more viable, it can only be considered after such a land exchange takes place.  The National Environmental Policy Act requires that the land currently held by the private land owner must be avoided as it is designated wilderness.  The proposed exchange must occur first, thereby removing the wilderness designation, so that the Juneau Creek alternative could receive further consideration.  It is very unlikely that this project will receive the national attention required to have NEPA revised by Congress.

Comment: I have some advice for the author of this article - don't go _looking_ for reasons to be offended.

It isn't perfect world - plenty of truly offensive statements and actions will come your way no matter what you do.  If you go looking for reasons to be offended, you _will_ find them, and you'll drive yourself nuts in the process.

Here's the thing about age - it catches up with us all.  We'll all at some point find ourselves holding a menu out at arms length to read it better - we'll all wake up some morning with joints that hurt for no apparent reason - we'll all walk into a room at some point and laugh at ourselves for forgetting why we did.  Sure, some people are condescending, but moaning about "ageism" isn't going to help that.

All we can do is smile and attempt to deal with it - age and the occasional thoughtless young person both - with a little bit of grace.

Today the crescent appears in flags of many countries which are predominantly Muslim, and  the Red Crescent Society performs humanitarian endeavors similar to the Red Cross.

Comment: Not sure what the terms are on the provincial cash, but here's what the federal ''loan'' is about:

Financial Post, Feb 2017;
''The federal government’s $372.5-million loan to Bombardier may not be fully repaid for 15 years, the company said Thursday.
The interest-free loan is “royalty repayable,” Bombardier chief financial officer John Di Bert said, providing details for the first time on the terms of the government aid that was announced earlier this month.
“That means that it will be repaid on either a function of business jet deliveries or CSeries unit deliveries,” Di Bert told analysts on the company’s fourth-quarter earnings call.
“It will be over a significant amount of time,” he added. “The program runs for about 15 years including a bit of a grace period the first two years, so no repayments for the first two years.”

No interest, no payback for first 2 years, 15 years to pay, contingent on sales and deliveries.

Comment: Two things to remember.  First, around 2002 was the peak of PERS retirement payouts.  Changes to PERS have been bringing down pensions ever since then.  Secondly, be cautious about the "% over final salary' figures.   Your teacher friend gets annual 2% COLAs while her final salary stays the same.  That is comparing apples-to-oranges fifteen years later.  It would be more informative to compare her PERS now to what she would be making if she had not retired.  Based on the many teachers I know, her PERS is less than what teachers make now.

Comment: Hikers at least have opportunity to use good judgment: "Hmm...this area is completely encircled by head-high brush.  I can't see far in any direction.  I'd better not go in there."

Runners have less time/opportunity to do so by virtue of the rate at which they're moving, but can still sometimes change course to avoid danger.  Mountain-yuppies hurtling at speed down low-visibility trails have still less opportunity, again simply by virtue of rate-of-travel.

Which as been the point all along--moving rapidly through low-visibility terrain in bear country is dangerous--doesn't matter whether you're running, biking or sliding down on a piece of cardboard.  Moreover, the danger isn't only for you, but for others on the trail endangered by your irresponsible behavior, and of course the bears themselves.

I oppose bear-baiting.  Even by reckless morons who volunteer to be the bait--because, AGAIN, they risk others' lives besides their own.

Comment: Electric car is much simpler device - you have battery and electric motor. No oil changes, head gaskets, no slipping transmissions, no plugged catalytic converters. The only issue is energy density and cost of batteries. Once battery tech is ready _all_ cars will be electric, and we will remember days of internal combustion engines the same way we remember now having to grease bearing nipples or having to double clutch non-synchronized transmissions.

While I prefer front engined rear wheel driven large-displacement naturally aspirated cars with a manual transmissions, you have to realize that these are not the future for the mainstream transportation. The future is an electric econobox with some self-driving capabilities.

Comment: Nowhere in the constitution does it confer any individual right to either the minerals rights, or even an individual right to the revenue.   Section 8.2 of the constitution requires the legislature to provide for the ...development..of all natural resources belonging to the State . . . for the maximum benefit of its people.    Whether the maximum benefit is provided for by payments to each individual citizen, or by utilizing the revenue from those resources for the general fund to eliminate or reduce broadbased taxes is really what the debate should be.     But no.   You do not, as an individual, have an an ownership right in the natural resources, nor do you have an individual right to a dividend from the Permanent Fund.   The constitution states that:  "All income from the permanent fund shall be deposited into the general fund unless otherwise provided by law"   This is what the Constitution says.    People should read this:  http://w3.legis.state.ak.us/docs/pdf/citizens_guide.pdf

Comment: "Say a prayer for all the departed during this month"....That comes naturally for some of  us raised in the Catholic tradition of commemorating All Soul's Day. Back in the 50's, the day started with obligatory Mass at Church with the pre Communion reading of 100's of names of each family that wished their dearly departed to be remembered... (paid by stipend, of course). For us fidgety,  grade schoolers, this ritual seemed endless. Of more interest was the afternoon 1 1/2 mile walk to the Catholic cemetery where over 350 of us students followed our pastor parading up and down the pathways reciting the rosary and the Litany of the Saints contemplating, in the blur of our late afternoon malaise, the various monuments to the departed, from the grandiose vaults of the Italian families to the modest headstones of the less affluent. The engraved names were familiar to us; most of them were the ancestors of our fellow students. One could not help being forever touched  by the experience.

Comment: Andrew Leach's unconvincing response to criticism of Justin Trudeau's climate policies by David Suzuki and Bill McKibben is notable for what it omits. It includes no discussion of the 1.5 - 2 ˚C targets agreed in Paris, what sort of global emission reductions are necessary to meet them, and the consequences of warming left unchecked. It similarly ignores Canada's excessive historical and per capita emissions, and the political and moral necessity for "contraction and convergence" in which countries with the highest emissions cut fastest and deepest. He also ignores the cost of locking in high-carbon infrastructure like pipelines which are economically intended to run for decades, but will need to be shut down early as part of concerted global climate action. Leach's "take what you can get, we could do less" message is an unsatisfactory response to the urgent challenge of climate change, and its not one that Trudeau or Canadians should accept.

Milan Ilnyckyj
Toronto

Comment: Too often the culture/education issue is seen as 'either/or'.  It does make sense to teach universally applicable, and employable skills with culturally relevant examples. Math and science especially make more sense when the concepts are related to something the student already has experience with.  The best education for any student is one that understands where they are coming from, teaches the ability to critique logic and society (regardless of whose logic or society), and gives them the tools that lets the student have options in how they choose to live.  

I think we can all agree that a good education teaches mixture of basic skills, critical thinking, knowledge of how to research and evaluate claims. This would be trans-cultural but inevitably taught in cultural contexts (relevant or alien). 

But schools can only do so much and are constrained by the level of support and choices of the family and community.

Comment: This will test two things - Junior's spine and the concept of free flow of goods across Canada, through separate provincial jurisdictions.

The second one has the potential to be a nation breaker: if one province can effectively embargo the goods of another province then essentially the landlocked provinces (Alberta and Saskatchewan) may as well leave Confederation. Whether or not they would be better off is open to question, but they would certainly be no worse off.

Comment: It now seems the West Eugene EmX (currently under construction) is two halves of two different routes.  

The planners have discovered that "feeding" River Rd, Hwy 99, and West 11th will require three buses every 10 minutes on 6th/7th Avenues, which is too big of a bus concentrated on these avenues.  So, the latest proposal I have heard is to feed 99 using 13th/11th to Chambers (from the downtown station), and feeding West 11th from 6th/7th to Garfield.  That means buses will crisscross on two parallel streets, only two blocks apart.  

Maybe they should have planned the overall system first, to avoid the apparent crisscrossing on the five block sections of Chambers and Garfield.  West 11th should be feed by 13th/11th, but the city council rejected that alternative several years ago; setting-up an appearance of halves of two different routes.

With all the years of planning, meetings, expense, etc. I now think the 6th/7th & W. 11th route never should have been available to the council.

Comment: All I've seen in my research coming out of California is that the Motor Voter Registration law did not make it legal for undocumented people with drivers licenses to vote.  I've seen NOTHING that specifically says they weren't registered to vote under Motor Voter Registration.  And I've seen nothing to indicate that California has a system in place to check the votes for legality.  Nor have I seen anything that says those licenses issued to illegals did not fall under the automatic voter registration under the MVR.  If you can document your claim, I'd like to see it.

As far as I can tell, the only difference between a regular drivers license and one issue to an undocumented person is that the latter has a statement on the front: "Subject to federal restrictions."  Other than that, I doubt any distinction is made the the state database.  Feel free to correct me with documentation.

Comment: "Read up on the Vietnam war veterans who were heavy heroin addicts, ..."

That's a very good point. But they were heroin addicts in Vietnam because there was no hope and this was how they coped. Coming home, they had a home to come to - family, a job, a future. If what they came back to wasn't any better than the hopelessness they had in Vietnam, though, they would have continued as addicts.

Look at so many vets today and in the past that have slipped through the cracks after their service. It was a problem the Soviet Union experienced with their war in Afghanistan.
